chapter.p: 1The oracle of the wilderness of the sea:
As storm winds passing over in the Negev,

ul.li1: it comesLiterally “to come” from the desert,

chapter.p: 2A hard revelation is told to me;
I put an end to all of her sighing.

ul.li1: 3Therefore my loins are filled with anguish;
ul.li2: pangs have seized me, like the pangs of a woman giving birth.
ul.li1: I am too bent to hear,Literally “bent from hearing,” which could also mean “bent because of what I heard”
ul.li2: I am too dismayed to see.Literally “dismayed from seeing,” which could also mean “dismayed because of what I saw”
the twilight I desiredLiterally “of my desire” broughtLiterally “put” me fear.
smearThat is, prepare with oil the shield!

chapter.p: 6For the Lord said this to me:

ul.li2: He must announce what he sees.

ul.li1: “Lord, I am standing on the watchtower continually by day,
ul.li2: and I am standing at my post throughoutLiterally “all of” the night.
ul.li1: 9And look at this! A man’s a chariot is coming,

ul.li2: And all the images of her gods areHebrew “is” smashed on the ground!”
and the son of my threshing floor,

chapter.p: I will announce to you what I have heard from Yahweh of hosts, the God of Israel.
One is calling to me from Seir,

ul.li1: You will spend the night in the thicket in a desert-plateau,The Hebrew for “in a desert-plateau” is the same as for “concerning Arabia” in the preceding line
14When you happen to meetLiterally “Toward encountering” the thirsty, bring water.
ul.li2: Inhabitants of the land of Tema came to meet the fugitive with his bread.
ul.li1: 15For they have fled from the swords,
ul.li2: from the drawn sword and the bent bow,
and from the heaviness of the battle.

chapter.p: 16For the Lord said this to me:
“In one more year,Literally “In yet a year” like the years of a hired worker,

ul.li1: all the glory of Kedar will come to an end.
ul.li2: 17And the remainder of the number of the bowsHebrew “bow” of the warriors of the sons of Kedar will be few.”

chapter.p: For Yahweh, the God of Israel, has spoken.
